Key Laboratory of Biomass Chemical Engineering of Ministry of Education, College of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310058 China 1 These authors contributed equally to this work Sorbitol production involves glucose hydrogenation, which requires co-adsorption of glucose and hydrogen on the catalyst surface for high catalytic performance. Binary alloy catalysts can modulate substrate adsorption to achieve better catalytic performance than Raney Ni. Herein, we established a pioneering DFT/ML approach to investigate the adsorption energies of glucose (ΔEGCHO) and H atoms (ΔEH) on 1155 binary alloy catalysts. The Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LGBM) algorithm proved the most effective ML model, predicting ΔEGCHO and ΔEH with R² values of 0.785 and 0.636, respectively. Microkinetic simulation demonstrated a correlation between catalytic activity and adsorption energy, revealing high-performance catalyst screening criteria as ΔEGCHO = −1.45 to −0.65 eV and ΔEH = −0.55–0.00 eV. Nine possible binary alloy catalysts with high predicted activity were identified, with Pd3Mg performing best. The present study highlights the potential of the DFT/ML-assisted approach in the development of efficient glucose hydrogenation binary alloy catalysts. Graphical Abstract Keywords Binary catalysts Glucose hydrogenation Density functional theory Machine learning Microkinetic simulation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogenation is a crucial chemical process widely used in coal, petrochemicals, and fine chemical industry; over 25 % of chemical transformations involve at least one step of hydrogenation, making it one of the most important process in catalysis [1,2]. Among these, sorbitol, a bio-based platform chemical derived from the hydrogenation of glucose, has become the most highly demanded sugar polyol due to its versatile applications, including food additives, cosmetics, and bio-based polymer synthesis [3,4]. Industrially, glucose hydrogenation is typically catalyzed by metal catalysts such as Raney Ni, and the mechanism involves hydrogen adsorption and dissociation on the catalyst surface, followed by glucose adsorption, with two successive H atoms bonding to the unsaturated CO bonds [5–8]. For efficient glucose hydrogenation to sorbitol, the ideal catalyst should exhibit appropriate adsorption energies for both glucose (ΔEGCHO) and hydrogen (ΔEH) to achieve a stable co-adsorption of the substrates for the reaction to proceed [9–11]. Additionally, it is vital to lower the free energy barrier and increase the reaction turnover frequency (TOF) to enable the reaction to occur under milder conditions [12,13]. Binary alloy catalysts are often considered to be efficient hydrogenation catalysts [14–18]. For instance, Fu et al. synthesized Fe-Ni/CB catalyst with a higher catalytic glucose hydrogenation activity than single Fe/CB and Ni/CB catalysts, moreover, the FeNi alloy catalyst exhibited superior advantages over monometallic the Ni catalyst in terms of stability[14]. Similarly, Romero et al. prepared a RuNi alloy catalyst with a total loading of ca. 3 % (ww−1) on silica MCM-48, and performed the glucose hydrogenation under a mild condition of 120 °C and 2.5 MPa H2 [17]. Both of the above suggested that the doped Fe or Ru atoms were involved in the adsorption of glucose, which enhanced glucose adsorption and thus promoted hydrogenation. Du et al. developed a highly efficient Cu-Ni/SiO2 catalysts for xylose hydrogenation, showing high catalytic activity in a moderate condition of 100 °C and 3 MPa H2 [18]. In addition, Du et al. found that the activation energy of hydrogenation on the alloy catalyst was much lower than that of the pure metal by experiment. Therefore, finding binary alloy catalysts with suitable composition and combination is an effective way to realize efficient glucose hydrogenation under moderate conditions. However, the composition and ratio of binary alloys are complex, and it is tedious to screen them experimentally one by one. Currently, the machine learning (ML) method has been successfully used to accelerate first-principle calculations for catalysts screening. The ML algorithms applied to density functional theory (DFT) databases can efficiently predict adsorption energy, formation energy, and transition state energy barriers with relatively low computational cost, thereby accelerating the screening of catalysts [19–21]. In addition, researchers often combined microkinetic simulations with ML predictions to determine relationship between catalyst activity/selectivity and the structural properties [22–27]. Liu et al. proposed microkinetic simulations to search for activity ranges by using the formation energy of C and O atoms as descriptors, with excellent ML prediction accuracy, they finally succeeded to select 48 promising binary alloy catalysts for steam methanol reforming [25]. Similarly, Yan et al. performed an unsupervised ML method based on the bisecting k-means hierarchical clustering algorithm to determine the stable adsorption configurations over binary alloy catalysts for ester hydrogenation, and in this case, microkinetic simulation was used to explain the trend in the dimethyl oxalate hydrogenation activity and selectivity by using C and O adsorption energies as two descriptors [27]. Although these valuable results have successfully screened promising catalysts by combining ML algorithm and microkinetic simulations, screening of glucose hydrogenation binary alloys remains a challenge due to the complexity of the glucose adsorption, referred to by its multi-point adsorption mode and the anisotropy of the binary alloys. In this study, as depicted in Fig. 1, we aim to identify highly effective binary alloy catalysts for glucose hydrogenation by accessible features and DFT calculations to train machine learning (ML) models. These models accurately predicted the adsorption energies of glucose and hydrogen atoms on the (111) surfaces of AxB4-x binary alloy catalysts (where A represented the active site for hydrogenation and B denoted the assistant metal). A dataset comprising 144 randomly selected binary alloy catalysts was utilized for model construction, with the results indicating that the LGBM model achieved superior accuracy. Subsequently, adsorption energies for 1011 binary alloy catalysts were predicted. Additionally, a microkinetic simulation was developed to elucidate the volcano relationship between adsorption and catalytic activity. Based on these findings, nine candidates with promising hydrogenation activity were identified. Finally, DFT calculations were employed to validate these screening results and explore the correlation between electronic structure properties and adsorption energies. Although due to insufficient databases and the difficulty of measuring preparation costs, it is difficult to fully consider the cost of catalysts, this hybrid DFT/ML/microkinetic simulation approach demonstrates its potential for the rational design of efficient binary alloy catalysts for various high-activity hydrogenation applications. 2 Methods 2.1 DFT calculation All DFT calculations were performed using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [28]. The electronic structures were calculated with the Perdew−Burke−Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-correlation functional within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [29]. The interaction between the atomic core electrons was described by the projector augmented wave (PAW) method [30]. The energy cutoff was set to 400 eV, and the force threshold for the optimization of the adsorption structures was 0.03 eV/Å. Self-consistent field calculations were terminated when the energy change was smaller than 10−5 eV. Grimme’s DFT-D3 method was employed to account for van der Waals interactions between the reactants and the catalyst [31]. Five-layer AxB4-x (X = 1, 2, 3) bimetal alloys’ (111) slabs with a 4 × 4 supercell were constructed. It needs to be acknowledged that this modeling approach is speculative, as not all the investigated binary alloys possess a stable fcc structure and (111) crystalline surfaces. To eliminate interactions between the slabs, a vacuum of 20 Å was applied in all models. Since the reduction in computational accuracy has little effect on the magnitude of the calculated adsorption energy (Table S1), in order to increase the speed of the computation, a Γ-point grid was used for calculation of adsorption energy as well as thermodynamic processes, while a (3 ×3 ×1) k-point grid was used for extra electronic structure calculation. The structures of transition states and reaction barriers of elementary steps on all surfaces were computed using the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method [32]. The Gibbs free energy of the adsorption states and the surface reaction mechanism for glucose hydrogenation over bimetal alloys were calculated under common reaction conditions (403 K, 4 MPa). More detailed computational methods are provided in the Supporting Information. 2.2 Machine learning All ML algorithms were implemented using the open-source Scikit-learn package in the Python 3 environment [33]. In this work, three different supervised ML algorithms were selected: Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LGBM), Multilayer Perceptron (MLP), and Support Vector Regression (SVR) [34–36]. The coefficient of determination (R² score) and the root-mean-square error (RMSE) were used to evaluate the accuracy of the ML models. A larger R² score and a smaller RMSE indicated a high-performance model. Detailed ML methods are described in the Supporting Information. 2.3 Microkinetic simulation The microkinetic simulations were performed using the open-source CatMAP code, based on the mean-field approach and the steady-state approximation, including a self-consistent description of adsorbate-adsorbate interactions [37]. In the microkinetic model, the adsorption free energies of GCHO* and H* (ΔGGCHO and ΔGH) were used as descriptors, with the calculated energetics on (111) surfaces serving as input for the coverage relations. The theoretical turnover frequencies (TOF) were then fitted with a parabolic function to construct the activity volcano, using the ΔGGCHO and ΔGH as activity descriptors. Further details of the microkinetic simulations were provided in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The ML-assisted prediction of the adsorption energies of glucose and H atom AxB4-x alloys were constructed, where the A metal served as the active catalytic center and was selected from one of the 11 common hydrogenation metals: Cr, Co, Ni, Cu, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Ir, Pt, and Au. The B metal, acting as the assistance, was chosen from 35 transition or main group elements [3,38–40]. The parameter x, representing the proportion of metal A, could be 1, 2, or 3, allowing for the formation of alloys in different compositions. This construction resulted in a data space of 1155 alloy species, from which 144 species were randomly selected for DFT calculations. According to previous work[6–8], glucose (GCHO) hydrogenation went through the following five steps: Step 1: GCHO+ *→GCHO* (ΔGGCHO) Step 2: H2+ 2 * →2H* (ΔGH) Step 3: GCHO* +H* →GCHO-HTS* →GCHOH* (ΔGTS1) Step 4: GCHOH* +H* →GCHOH-HTS* →GCH2OH* (ΔGTS2) Step 5: GCH2OH* →GCH2OH+ * (ΔGdes) The first and second steps involved the co-adsorption of glucose and H atom on the catalyst. ΔGGCHO and ΔGH represented the adsorption free energies for glucose and H atom on the catalyst surface, respectively. As shown in Fig. S1, glucose could adopt several possible adsorption configurations on the (111) surface of different alloy catalysts: AB3 alloy: 1. The O atom of the aldehyde group was adsorbed on the bridge sites of the neighboring A and B metals, and the C atom was adsorbed on the top site of the B metal. A2B2 alloy: 2. The O atom was adsorbed on the bridge sites of the two neighboring A metals, and the C atom was adsorbed on the top site of the B metal. 3. The O atom was adsorbed on the bridge sites of two neighboring A and B metals, and the C atom was adsorbed on the top site of the A metal. A3B alloy: 4. The O atom was adsorbed on the bridge sites of two neighboring A metals, and the C atom was adsorbed on the top site of the B metal. 5. The O atom was adsorbed on the bridge sites of the two neighboring A metals, and the C atom was also adsorbed on the top sites of the A metal. The adsorption of H atom had the following possible configurations (as shown in Fig. S2): AB3 and A2B2 alloys: 1. The H atom was adsorbed on the fcc site formed by one A metal and two B metals. All possible adsorption configurations of GCHO* and H* were optimized and the corresponding adsorption energies (ΔEGCHO and ΔEH) were calculated using DFT, and the adsorption energies of the most stable configurations were used as the target variables for the data set. The respective adsorption energies of the two substrates in the co-adsorption reaction had been widely used to explore the level of hydrogenation activity, but the specific mechanism needed to be further explored [10,41,42]. The selection of features was crucial for building a high-precision machine learning model, necessitating consideration of the respective physicochemical properties of the A and B metals. The commonly used physicochemical properties were defined as descriptors, divided into two categories: geometric and electronic structures. The geometric structure was represented by the atomic radius ratios (RB/RA) of the A and B metals, the radius of the A metal atoms (RA), the atomic numbers (NA, NB), and atomic masses (MA, MB). The electronic structure was characterized by the number of outer electrons (SA, SB), the number of valence electrons (VA, VB), electronegativity (XA, XB), first ionization energies (IA, IB), and electron affinity energies (EA, EB). Additionally, the proportion of A metal (A%) was included to differentiate alloy catalysts with varying composition. Not all features were essential for ML model prediction; redundant features could decrease model accuracy and waste computational resources. Therefore, the feature importance analysis function in the Light gradient boosting machine (LGBM) model was employed to rank and select the most significant features. A dataset containing 144 binary alloy catalysts was input into the LGBM algorithm within the Scikit-learn framework for preliminary training. The feature importance results were shown in Fig. S3. To further evaluate the performance of different ML models, we constructed and compared the other two models with LGBM: Multilayer perceptron (MLP), and Support vector regression (SVR), evaluating their accuracy in predicting the target variables. Two statistical metrics, R² and RMSE, were used to measure the accuracy of the three models in predicting the target variables ΔEGCHO and ΔEH. The prediction accuracy varied with the number of features, as shown in Fig. S4. For predicting ΔEGCHO, five features: RA, SA, EA, MA, and MB, were found to be the least important. The prediction accuracies (R²) of the three ML models progressively improved as these features were removed one by one. The LGBM model’s prediction accuracy increased to an R² of 0.710 with 12 features, the MLP model’s accuracy stabilized at an R² of 0.629, and the SVR model’s accuracy slightly increased to an R² of 0.520. Ultimately, as shown in Fig. 2a, RB/RA, IB, VB, XB, and VA were identified as the five most important features for predicting ΔEGCHO. For predicting ΔEH, further feature streamlining was required. When the number of features was reduced to eight, the prediction accuracy of the three models improved significantly. The R² values for the LGBM, MLP, and SVR models increased to 0.588, 0.410, and 0.450, respectively. Eventually, as shown in Fig. 2b, RB/RA, NB, EB, VB, and RA were determined to be the five most important features for predicting ΔEH. It could be seen that in both models, the properties of metal B were more important than those of metal A. This was due to the fact that metal A was all some metals with good hydrogenation properties and they were all very close to each other in substrate adsorption, whereas this was not the case for metal B. B metals covered almost the entire periodic table of elements, and the atomic properties of some of these metals were so different that they did not only affect the energy band structure of the A-site metal, but might even be involved in the adsorption configurations of the substrates. Interestingly, the radius ratio (RB/RA) was the most important feature in the prediction models for both ΔEGCHO and ΔEH. This was due to the fact that the effect of RB/RA on the adsorption was multifaceted compared to other features. First, the radius ratio of the two metal atoms significantly affected the lattice parameter of the alloy, which led to changes in the metal spacing on the (111) surface and ultimately changed the energy band structure of the alloy surface. In addition, a large radius difference caused the (111) surface to become “bumpy”, forming valleys at small atoms and peaks at large atoms. This might affect the angle of orbital overlap between the adsorbed atoms (O, C, H) and the active site metal, thus affecting the magnitude of the adsorption energy. The radius was also a reflection of electronegativity to some extent, and thus RB/RA was also a reflection of the difference in electronegativity between two metals. Three ML models were systematically adjusted to achieve more accurate prediction performance. The final results for the key hyperparameters of each model were shown in Tables S2-4. Accordingly, the prediction accuracy of each model for the two target variables, ΔEGCHO and ΔEH, was statistically presented in Fig. 2c, with specific comparison Figures for the three ML models displayed in Fig. 2d-i. For predicting ΔEGCHO, the LGBM model demonstrated the best performance, achieving the highest R² (0.785) and the lowest RMSE (0.476 eV). In contrast, the MLP and SVR models exhibited lower prediction accuracy, with the MLP model yielding an R² of 0.680 and an RMSE of 0.576 eV, and the SVR model showing an R² of 0.555 and an RMSE of 0.679 eV. Similarly, for predicting ΔEH, the LGBM model also showed superior performance, with the highest R² (0.636) and the lowest RMSE (0.163 eV). Overall, the LGBM model achieved the best prediction power for both target variables among the three models. Consequently, the ΔEGCHO and ΔEH on the (111) surfaces of 1044 binary alloy catalysts could be efficiently predicted using the well-tuned LGBM model. The prediction results were summarized in Fig. S5-10. 3.2 The relationship between adsorption and hydrogenation on binary alloy catalysts The adsorption energies (ΔEGCHO and ΔEH) alone were insufficient criteria for evaluating the catalytic performance of catalysts. While some studies had attempted to use transition state energy barriers (ΔGTS) to estimate catalytic activity, however calculating ΔGTS via DFT was time-consuming and impractical for large datasets [43–45]. In addition, ΔGTS was not a comprehensive criterion. To address this, we developed a mean-field microkinetic model using the CatMAP code, which included explicit adsorbate−adsorbate interactions, to study the activity for glucose hydrogenation over different binary alloy surfaces under common reaction conditions (403 K, PGCHO = 0.1 bar, and PH2 = 40 bar). We randomly selected 14 alloys from the 144 alloys in the ML dataset to calculate the thermodynamic process of glucose hydrogenation according to the “adsorption-hydrogenation-desorption” mechanism. The formation energies (ΔG) of intermediates and transition states were presented in Table S5. The adsorption free energies of the feedstock (ΔGGCHO, ΔGH2) were set as the baseline value of 0 eV, and the formation energy of product (ΔGGCH2OH) was calculated via DFT to be −1.13 eV. Fig. 3a, b demonstrated the coverage as a function of ΔGGCHO and ΔGH2 during the co-adsorption of glucose and hydrogen. In Fig. 3a, when the coordinates of ΔGGCHO and ΔGH2 were within the bright white region, the adsorption free energy of GCHO* (ΔGGCHO) was much larger than that of H* (ΔGH), resulting in the catalyst adsorbing only glucose. Conversely, in Fig. 3b, when the coordinates were in the bright white region, the value of ΔGGCHO was similar to or less than that of ΔGH. Due to the large spatial resistance of glucose molecules, the catalyst could only adsorb smaller H atom on the (111) surface of catalyst. When the ΔGGCHO and ΔGH2 coordinates were located in the common dark blue region, neither glucose nor H atom could be adsorbed on the (111) surface of the catalyst under the reaction conditions. For glucose hydrogenation, the formation of a stable co-adsorption structure was required, therefore, the above three situations were not conducive to hydrogenation. Only when the ΔGGCHO and ΔGH2 coordinates were near the intersection line of the bright white and dark blue regions, both glucose and H atoms could be adsorbed on the catalyst, which was required for hydrogenation. Furthermore, the relationship between the hydrogenation TOF values and ΔGGCHO and ΔGH was determined from simulations based on the intermediate adsorption free energies and transition states energy barriers, as shown in Fig. 3c. Brighter colors and higher TOF values indicated higher catalytic activity of the alloy catalysts. Among the 14 alloy catalysts, Pt3Al, RhTc3, and Ir3Ru exhibited high catalytic activity, with TOF values located in the third high-brightness region. In contrast, Cu2Ni2, Pt2Cd2, Pd3Cd, and Rh3Ag were found in the dark-colored regions, indicating poor catalytic activity. The remaining eight alloys were in regions of general brightness, suggesting relatively average catalytic activity. Moreover, when ΔGGCHO and ΔGH on the alloy surface were between −0.4 and 0.0 eV and −0.37 to 0.07 eV, respectively, the TOF values for glucose hydrogenation were in the brightest region of the figure. This indicated that alloy catalysts with ΔGGCHO and ΔGH within these ranges were likely to exhibit highest catalytic hydrogenation activity. This finding provided a basis for screening the ML-predicted adsorption energy results. It was also notable that the contour plots of TOF values showed a thin and elongated central highlighted region, suggesting that the adsorption energy of glucose within a reasonable range was more critical for catalytic activity in hydrogenation compared to the adsorption energy of H atom. According to Table S6, it was observed that the free energy correction values (ZPE − TΔS) for GCHO* and H* on various alloy catalysts consistently ranged from + 4.30 to + 4.42 eV and + 0.16 to + 0.19 eV, respectively. In contrast, the free energy correction values for isolated glucose and H2 remained constant at + 3.41 eV and + 0.02 eV, respectively. Thus, it was reasonable to transform screening conditions related to adsorption free energy (ΔG) into conditions based on adsorption energy (ΔE), which were more easily obtained through DFT calculations (i.e., ΔEGCHO between −1.25 ∼ −0.85 eV and ΔEH between −0.55 ∼ −0.1 eV). Considering potential errors in ΔEGCHO and ΔEH predictions by the ML model, with RMSE values of 0.476 eV and 0.163 eV, respectively, the screening criteria were appropriately widened to ΔEGCHO between −1.45 ∼ −0.65 eV and ΔEH between −0.55 ∼ 0.00 eV to avoid omitting potentially effective catalysts due to prediction uncertainties. It was also important to verify the existence and structural stability of the alloys before the screening process began, and a database search of the 14 alloys revealed that due to the structural instability of Tc, no stable alloys structure of RhTc3 have been found (Table S7). Therefore, in subsequent work, alloys containing Tc will not be considered. Based on these criteria, 1155 alloy catalysts were screened for predicted performance, which was further validated by DFT calculations. The structurally stable alloy catalysts with ΔEGCHO and ΔEH values in the determination range were identified. Finally, nine candidates met these criteria, comparative data with Raney Ni were used for benchmarking, and the statistical results were shown in Table S8. Similarly, the existence of the nine alloys screened was verified and it was found that they all had similar stable cubic structures found in databases or literature. As depicted in Fig. 3d, the white dot represented the position of the Raney Ni (RN Ni) catalyst used as a reference in the TOF contour plot, locating within the fifth brightness region. In contrast, all nine binary alloy catalysts screened through ML-assisted methods were situated in brighter regions on the contour plot, indicating superior catalytic hydrogenation activity compared to Raney Ni. Among these, Rh3Al, Ru2Ga2, CrRe3, and Cu3Al occupied the third and fourth brightness regions, showcasing slightly enhanced catalytic performance over Raney Ni. Cu2Mg2, Pd2Mg2, Rh2V2, and Rh2Mg2 were positioned in the second brightness region, demonstrating excellent hydrogenation catalytic activity. Notably, Pd3Mg stood out in the first brightness region, exhibiting the highest catalytic hydrogenation activity among all alloy catalysts. 3.3 Theoretic analysis Based on the structure found in literature or database, the (111) surface structures for calculation of 9 screened alloy as well as Raney Ni (RN Ni) catalysts were built and optimized (Fig. S11). Fig. S12 and S13 illustrated the free energy diagrams of catalytic hydrogenation for eight high-performance catalysts located in the second and third brightness zones, respectively. Fig. 4a showed the free energy diagram of catalytic hydrogenation for the Pd3Mg alloy catalyst with the best performance. Fig. 4b quantifies the energy barriers (ΔGRDS) of rate-determining steps for all ten catalysts. The ΔGRDS for these eight high-performance alloy catalysts ranged from 0.71 to 1.54 eV (red and blue color), comparable to that of Raney Ni catalyst, without a clear trend indicating whether addition of the H atom to the C or O atom of the aldehyde group became the rate-determining step of hydrogenation. These binary alloy catalysts not only exhibited similar abilities to reduce ΔGRDS as Raney Ni but also formed stable co-adsorption configurations due to their more rational adsorption energy relationships, resulting in superior catalytic activity. Among them, Cu3Al and Cu2Mg2 were noteworthy as non-noble binary alloy catalysts with significant experimental relevance. Particularly, Pd3Mg demonstrated the best catalytic performance by achieving a highly stable co-adsorption configuration with a very high TOF value. In addition, the ΔGRDS for hydrogenation on the Pd3Mg (111) surface was only 0.44 eV, significantly lower than that of other catalysts. This highlighting the exceptional catalytic activity of the Pd3Mg catalyst. The side reactions of glucose on the catalyst surface have an important effect on the selectivity, and according to our previous work [6], the dehydrogenation of cyclic glucose to generate gluconolactone was the most influential, and the specific reaction pathway was shown in Fig. S14. The thermodynamic process of dehydrogenation on the surfaces of six binary alloys or metals (Pd3Mg, Pd2Mg2, Cu2Mg2, Rh2V2, Rh2Mg2 and Raney Ni) was calculated, and the results were shown in Fig. S15. The specific rate-determining step energy barrier of dehydrogenation (ΔGRDS) statistics in Fig. S16. It could be seen that all screened alloys had higher ΔGRDS of dehydrogenation compared to Raney Ni, this means that these alloys not only have excellent hydrogenation properties, but also help to limit side reactions. And it was interesting to note that the difficulty of the dehydrogenation reaction went up dramatically when the content of Mg increased. This might be due to the fact that as the content of Mg rises, the oxygen atom in intermediate 1 was more likely to form a chemical bond with Mg, thus making intermediate 1 much more stable and the second hydrogen atom more difficult to remove. In addition, the C-C hydrogenolysis side reaction was often mentioned, so we also performed thermodynamic calculations for the C-C hydrogenolysis reaction on the surface of the screened binary alloy catalysts and Raney Ni. As shown in Fig. S17, glucose and H atoms first formed a co-adsorption structure on the catalysts, and then, H atoms added to the C-C bond closest to the surface of the catalysts to realize the hydrogenolysis of the C-C bond. The free energy diagram (Fig. S18) showed that C-C hydrogenolysis reactions are difficult to occur on the surface of the screened alloy catalysts with an extremely high energy barrier (ΔGTS reaching 3 – 4 eV). This might be due to the fact that the mild conditions and neutral environment of glucose hydrogenation were not suitable for the C-C hydrogenolysis reaction, which usually required the catalytic action of Lewis acid and high temperatures of about 235–250 °C to occur [46,47]. This was consistent with our previous experimental results, where we did not observe products of C-C hydrogenolysis, such as propylene glycol [6]. Pd3Mg showed excellent catalytic hydrogenation performance due to its favorable adsorption energy for both two substrates, in contrast to other Pd-based alloys that also shown outstanding hydrogenation catalytic activity but exhibited differences. Studies had reported that the matching of the 3d orbitals of the metal with the 1π orbitals of the aldehyde group was an important factor affecting the adsorption of glucose on the catalysts, and the important correlation between the d-band center and the adsorption of the substrate was also mentioned in the d-band theory proposed by Nørskov et al. [48–50], therefore, more than thirty binary Pd-based alloys with the same ratio of 3:1 had also been explored. The relationship between ΔEGCHO, ΔEH of the binary Pd-based alloys and the d-band center of the Pd atom were shown in Fig. 4c. The ΔEGCHO on the catalyst showed a linear relationship with the d-band center position (R2 = 0.52), and DFT calculations showed that the energy level of the glucose aldehyde’s 1π-orbital was −2.0 eV, which was exactly near the d-band center of the Pd-based alloys, resulting in a strong adsorption of glucose by the Pd-based alloys. Moreover, when the d-band center gradually decreased from −1.2 eV to −2.0 eV, the energy level of the glucose aldehyde’s 1π-orbital became much higher that of Pd’s d band orbital, more and more π-electron of aldehyde were transferred to the Pd’s 3d orbital of the alloy catalyst, which led to the enhancement of ΔEGCHO by the Pd-based alloys. When the d-band center of the Pd-based catalyst decreased to a value below −2.0 eV, electrons from the lower energy level orbitals on the aldehyde group would be moved to the Pd’s 3d orbital. This transfer resulted in an additional rise in the adsorption energy. However, if the d-band center was decreased much further, the favorable alignment between the Pd’s 3d orbital and the aldehyde’s 1π orbital would no longer exist, perhaps resulting in a decrease in adsorption energy. Meanwhile, as shown in Fig. S19, the ΔEH on the Pd-based alloys were not significantly related to the d-band center (R2 = 0.02), which was related to the co-adsorption structure of glucose and H atoms. In order to satisfied the hydrogenation conditions, H atom often needed to be adsorbed in the vicinity of large glucose molecules, which resulted in a large spatial resistance to the adsorption of H atom, possibly leading to an irrelevance between the d-band center and the adsorption energy of the H atom. Here we extended the application of d-band center theory to glucose hydrogenation and found an anomalous relationship between H atom adsorption and d-band center. This presented a fresh perspective on reactions based on complex co-adsorption structure, not only the interaction relationship between the two substrates and the catalyst might have an impact on the reaction, but also the interaction between them (either directly or indirectly through effects on the catalyst surface), which couldn’t be neglected. And in conjunction with the findings in the Section 2, the TOF values for the glucose hydrogenation were more sensitive to glucose adsorption energy, this suggested that we could focus on adjusting the position of the d-band center of the alloys to obtain a more appropriate glucose adsorption energy, which would allow us to achieve a theoretical guidance for the synthesis of hydrogenation alloy catalysts. 4 Conclusion This study utilized accessible features and DFT calculation results to train machine learning (ML) models for predicting adsorption energies of glucose (ΔEGCHO) and H atom (ΔEH) on AxB4-x binary alloy catalysts. A dataset comprising adsorption energies of 144 binary alloy catalysts was constructed, revealing that the physicochemical properties of assistant metals significantly influenced these energies. Among three ML algorithms tested, the Light gradient boosting machine (LGBM) model demonstrated superior performance with R² of 0.785 for ΔEGCHO and 0.636 for ΔEH, subsequently extended to predict these energies across the remaining binary alloy catalysts. Microkinetic simulations were conducted using DFT-calculated thermodynamic data from 14 randomly selected binary alloy catalysts, plotting catalyst TOF values against ΔGGCHO and ΔGH. Analysis indicated that catalysts with ΔGGCHO between −0.40 and 0.00 eV, and ΔGH between −0.37 and 0.07 eV, tended to exhibit higher TOF values. Consequently, screening criteria were established as ΔEGCHO between −1.45 and −0.65 eV, and ΔEH between −0.55 and 0.00 eV. ML predictions screened 1044 binary alloy catalysts, identifying nine with excellent catalytic hydrogenation performance, notably the Pd3Mg alloy with a ΔGTS of 0.44 eV. Furthermore, ΔEGCHO in Pd-based alloys was found to correlate linearly with the catalyst’s d-band center, extending the application of d-band center theory. coredata.dc:description: Sorbitol production involves glucose hydrogenation, which requires co-adsorption of glucose and hydrogen on the catalyst surface for high catalytic performance. Binary alloy catalysts can modulate substrate adsorption to achieve better catalytic performance than Raney Ni. Herein, we established a pioneering DFT/ML approach to investigate the adsorption energies of glucose (ΔEGCHO) and H atoms (ΔEH) on 1155 binary alloy catalysts. The Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LGBM) algorithm proved the most effective ML model, predicting ΔEGCHO and ΔEH with R² values of 0.785 and 0.636, respectively. Microkinetic simulation demonstrated a correlation between catalytic activity and adsorption energy, revealing high-performance catalyst screening criteria as ΔEGCHO = −1.45 to −0.65 eV and ΔEH = −0.55–0.00 eV. Nine possible binary alloy catalysts with high predicted activity were identified, with Pd3Mg performing best. The present study highlights the potential of the DFT/ML-assisted approach in the development of efficient glucose hydrogenation binary alloy catalysts.
